title: Modified Brain Injury Guideline (mBIG)
description: Defines management of traumatic brain injury by stratifying patients into three categories based on clinical and radiographic factors

ranges.interpretation: 6-hour ED observation with Q2 neurological assessments. No repeat head CT, no neurosurgery consult. Discharge when GCS 15.
Hospital admission to general medical floor for 24-48 hours. Q2 neurological assessments. No repeat head CT, no neurosurgery consult. Discharge when GCS 15.
Continue with standard of care at your institution. Requires neurosurgical consultation and intensive monitoring.

references: Joseph B, Friese RS, Sadoun M, Aziz H, Kulvatunyou N, Pandit V, et al. The BIG (brain injury guidelines) project: defining the management of traumatic brain injury by acute care surgeons. J Trauma Acute Care Surg. 2014 Oct;77(4):597-605. doi: 10.1097/TA.0000000000000379.

Hartwell EA, Fang R, Dzandu JK, Edwards KA, Walsh RM, Colombo CJ, Yarbrough K, Liu KC, Pasley JD, Mazzini FN, et al. A Multicenter Validation of the Modified Brain Injury Guidelines (mBIG): Are They Safe and Effective? J Trauma Acute Care Surg. 2022 Apr 1;92(4):e92-e98. doi: 10.1097/TA.0000000000003527.
formula: Hierarchical classification based on radiographic and clinical findings. mBIG 3 criteria override mBIG 2, and mBIG 2 criteria override mBIG 1.
notes: Applies only to traumatic brain injury patients with intracranial hemorrhage
Excludes patients with focal neurologic or pupillary findings
mBIG 1 patients can be safely discharged from ED after observation
mBIG 2 patients require hospital admission but not neurosurgical consultation
mBIG 3 patients require standard neurosurgical care
Validated in level 1 and 2 trauma centers
Significant cost savings demonstrated with implementation
